awd_titl_txt: Surfaces and Geometry and Topology of Quantum Link Invariants
awd_abstract_narration:
Knot theory studies knotted, closed loops in a three-dimensional space considered up to continuous transformations of the space. In mathematics, knots that cannot be transformed into one another without cutting and regluing the strings that form the loops are considered to be different from each other, or in other words, inequivalent. Key tools for distinguishing inequivalent knots are called knot invariants and these are essentially the properties of a knot that are preserved by continuous transformations of the space. In this project the PI will study the relationship between quantum knot invariants, a relatively less understood family, constructed from the ideas of quantum physics and mathematics. Central questions in quantum topology are broadly connected to the geometric topology of three-dimensional spaces, number-theoretic properties of polynomials assigned by quantum invariants, and the algebraic structures of quantum groups defining the theory. The project includes research plans for undergraduate and Master's students. The PI will also engage with "Girls Who Code" club meetings in service to the local community.   

The colored Jones polynomial is an important knot invariant that comes from the representation theory of quantum groups and lies at the heart of quantum topology, low-dimensional topology, and hyperbolic geometry.  In this project the PI and her collaborators will expand the correspondence between a state sum defining the colored Jones polynomial and properly embedded surfaces in a link complement, by applying the techniques of classical three-manifold topology and normal surface theory. The next part is to prove a categorified version of the Strong Slope Conjecture for colored Khovanov homology, which is a categorification of the colored Jones polynomial. The PI will evaluate the potential for this framework to provide new perspectives on the relationship of Khovanov homology to knot Floer homology, another link invariant that has been extensively studied with deep connections to other fields. The project will further study the stability properties of Khovanov homology. These results will be used to explore the contact-geometric properties of the transverse invariant defined by Plamenevskaya.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The project studies the relationship between knot invariants, which are mathematical objects defined from knots that can be used to tell them apart. In particular, the PI studied the relationship between quantum knot invariants called the colored Jones polynomial discovered by Fields medalist Vaughan Jones, and other more intrinsically motivated knot invariants such as boundary slopes and hyperbolic volume defined from the topology and the geometry of the knot.

 

Main Achievements

 

Intellectual merit

During the course of the project, the PI proved the slope conjecture for large families of Montesinos knots with van der Veen and Garoufalidis. More generally the PI established the relationship between colored Khovanov homology, the categorification of the color Jones polynomial, and normal surface theory. This was one of the core objectives of the project. In terms of application to low-dimensional topology, the PI with Kalfagianni established a connection between the degrees of the color Jones polynomial and the crossing numbers of satellite knots which allowed us to determine the crossing numbers of an infinite family of satellite knots. These were the first examples of this kind. Finally, Anghel and the PI defined a topological model for the HOMFLY-PT polynomial. The model gave a topological interpretation of a state sum definition of the HOMFLY-PT polynomial which does not rely on the representation of the knot as a braid. 

 

In other projects, the PI used the Jones polynomial to classify all the L-space knots that are 3-braids with Vafaee, determined Plamenevskaya's invariants for 3-braids with Hubbard, and discovered a relationship between the hyperbolic volume and the stable Khovanov homology of links.

 

The projects advanced the overarching goal of understanding the geometric and topological content of quantum link invariants. This was done by strengthening existing connections predicted by the slope conjecture and the volume conjecture, as well as finding new connections between low-dimensional topology and quantum link invariants as described in the preceding paragraphs. 

 

Broader impacts

 

The funding for the project supported the research of several undergraduate students at both the University of South Alabama, the PI's former institution, and Texas State University, the PIs current institution, the research of Masters graduate students, and supervising the Girls Who Code and Girls in Math club at the University of South Alabama. For undergraduate students, the project activities have inspired them to major in math or to take advanced math courses. For graduate students the projects activites engaged their interests in graduate studies in mathematics. The K-12 outreach activities were successful in igniting the participants' interests in math and computer science and broadened their participation in math competitions.

 

The funding for the project also supported the PIs travel to disseminate the results of the research projects and to initiate and sustain collaborations, both domestically and internationally. For example, the project with Anghel would not have been possible without the travel to Anghel's home institution in the UK to complete the preprint for publication. Other projects in progress with colleagues in Europe also would not have been possible without the travel support. The PI would like to express her gratitude for the support for the project provided by the National Science Foundation. 

 


Last Modified: 10/20/2024
Modified by: Christine R Lee
